title: Tilt your Maps and Turn Them into ggplot Plots
text: goal layer simplify whole process creating stacked tilted maps, often used scientific publications show different environmental layers geographical region. Tilting maps layering allows easily draw visual correlations environmental layers. Something line :

title: Tilt your Maps and Turn Them into ggplot Plots
text: can install development version layer GitHub :

title: Tilt your Maps and Turn Them into ggplot Plots
text: basic example shows solve common problem:
code: library(layer)  tilt_landscape_1 <- tilt_map(landscape_1) tilt_landscape_2 <- tilt_map(landscape_2, x_shift = 25, y_shift = 50) tilt_landscape_3 <- tilt_map(landscape_3, x_shift = 50, y_shift = 100) tilt_landscape_points <- tilt_map(landscape_points, x_shift = 75, y_shift = 150)  map_list <- list(tilt_landscape_1, tilt_landscape_2, tilt_landscape_3, tilt_landscape_points)  plot_tiltedmaps(map_list,                 layer = c("value", "value", "value", NA),                 palette = c("bilbao", "mako", "rocket", NA),                 color = "grey40")

title: Tilt your Maps and Turn Them into ggplot Plots
text: realistic looking data (DEM, drought, precipitation, wildfires continental USA):
code: tilt_landscape_1 <- tilt_map(dem_usa, y_tilt = 3) tilt_landscape_2 <- tilt_map(drought_usa, y_tilt = 3, x_shift = 15, y_shift = 25) tilt_landscape_3 <- tilt_map(prec_usa, y_tilt = 3, x_shift = 30, y_shift = 50) tilt_landscape_4 <- tilt_map(fire_usa, y_tilt = 3, x_shift = 45, y_shift = 65)  map_list <- list(tilt_landscape_1, tilt_landscape_2, tilt_landscape_3, tilt_landscape_4)  plot_tiltedmaps(map_list, palette = c("tofino", "rocket", "mako", "magma"), direction = c(-1, 1, 1, 1))
